title: 105_hr527
content: The "OPIC Abolition Act" terminates the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation will cease issuing insurance, loans, and securities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. It will be abolished 180 days after the enactment of the OPIC Abolition Act, with operations transferring to the Office of Management and Budget. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation will transfer its functions to the Office of Management and Budget, ceasing to renew contracts and agreements while winding up its affairs. Title IV of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 will be repealed, with funds being transferred upon the effective date of the repeal. Upon the repeal of Title IV of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, funds will be transferred to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget for the Corporation's functions. Any remaining balances will be deposited in the Treasury after contracts expire. SEC. 3. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. The repeal of certain provisions of law will not affect any existing orders, determinations, regulations, or contracts. These will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. Pending proceedings before the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will also not be affected by the repeal. The repeal of certain provisions of law will not affect existing orders, determinations, regulations, or contracts. Proceedings related to functions performed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked by the Director, a court, or by operation of law. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to issue regulations for the transfer of proceedings. The Act will not affect suits commenced before its repeal, and proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Liabilities incurred by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will not abate due to the Act. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's cause of action will not abate due to the Act. Any ongoing suits involving the Corporation will continue with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget as a party. Orders and actions of the Director will be subject to judicial review as if issued by the Corporation. Any statutory requirements for notice, hearings, action upon the record, or administrative review that apply to the Overseas Private Investment Corporation also apply to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget when exercising the Corporation's functions. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Title 5, United States Code is amended by removing specific positions at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Other amendments include changes to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Export Enhancement Act of 1988. Several sections of different acts, including the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 and the Higher Education Act of 1965, are amended by removing references to the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Several sections of different acts are amended by removing references to the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1996. The Democracy Act of 1989 is amended to include the Administrator of the Agency for International Development. The amendment applies to the annual report required under the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1996. Additionally, sections of the Support for East European Democracy Act of 1989 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed and amended, respectively.
